We generate the synthetic data from the underlying logistic regression model, with random standard Gaussian noise added to the linear predictor for each observation. The number of observations is n=500ğ‘›500n=500, and the number of covariates is
p=20ğ‘20p=20. We generate all elements of the data matrix ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x} from the standard Gaussian distribution. In this example, we compare the performance of the three models, fit using Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC), in particular with the No-U-Turn sampler (NUTS) fit in NumPyro [28], and two different variational approximations, a mean-field approximation and the amortized approximation. Note that the posterior approximation for the parameters ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta} and bğ‘b are the same throughout the two approximations, and the only difference comes in the variational approximation for the parameters ğ’›ğ’›\bm{z}. Table 2 shows the combination of models and algorithms that we consider fitting in this example.

references: Table 3 presents the test predictive accuracy and average test log-likelihood for the split NN and the hierarchical Bayes split NN with different values of the hyperparameter ÏğœŒ\rho (Ï=1,5,10ğœŒ1510\rho={1,5,10}). The results demonstrate that all variants of the hierarchical Bayes split NN outperform the standard split NN, with better performance observed for smaller values of ÏğœŒ\rho, which is expected, because using higher values of ÏğœŒ\rho is analogous to reducing the amount of signal that the set of auxiliary variables contains regarding the mean, which is the value of interest. Notably, higher variance is observed for larger values of ÏğœŒ\rho, which is intuitive as it introduces additional variance to the model.
